properties.comment:
This configuration describes the labels of options in SBMLsqueezer-related (graphical) user interfaces. Although the preferred way would be to have separate key-value pairs for actual labels and their corresponding tooltips, you may want to use just one key-value pair, in which the tooltip is located after the separator ";". Otherwise, please use the suffix "_TOOLTIP" to indicate a tooltip for some label.
Please see the JavaDoc for MessageFormatter and Formatter.
properties.entry: Specifies the file where SBMLsqueezer writes its SBML output.
If selected, the application will try to load the library libSBML for reading and writing SBML files, otherwise everything will be done with JSBML only, i.e., pure Java.
Consider all reactions to be enzyme-catalyzed
If true, all reactions within the network are considered to be enzyme-catalyzed reactions. If false (default), an explicit enzymatic catalyst must be assigned to a reaction to obtain this status.
If no spatial dimensions are defined for a compartment, the value defined by this option will be used as a default.
For compartments that are not yet initialized, SBMLsqueezer will use this value as the default initial size. By default this value is set to 1.0.
Here you can specify the default value that is set for newly created parameters. By default this value is 1.0.
Species are quantities in substance units if not specified differently.

This option allows users to specify that the numerical value of a species should be interpreted as a value given in substance units in cases where this has not yet been defined. If not selected, species with undefined meaning will be conceived as a quantity in concentration units.

If species are not yet initialized, SBMLsqueezer will use this value as initial amount or initial concentration of the species. Which kind of quantity is used, depends on whether the species has only substance units. This means, for species that are to be interpreted in terms of concentration, an initial concentration will be set, whereas an initial amount will be set if the species is to be interpreted in terms of molecule counts. By default this value is set to 1.0.

If this flag is set to true, a new rate law will be created for each reaction irrespective of whether there is already a rate law assigned to this reaction or not. If false (default), new rate laws are only generated if missing in the SBML file. Note that if this option is checked, already existing kinetic laws will be overwritten.
Ignore these species when creating laws

Allows the user to ignore species that are annotated with the given compound identifiers when creating rate laws for reactions that involve these species. For instance, water or single protons can often be ignored when creating rate equations, hence simplifying the resulting rate equations. Preselected are the KEGG compound identifiers for water and protons.

A simultaneous collision of a high number of reactants just by chance is very unlikely. Usually, these reactions proceed in a sequence of separate steps, each involving only very few molecules. Here you can specifiy the maximal number of reactants so that the reaction is still considered plausible. By default this value is set to 3. Note that this option is only available if you decide that this kind of warning should be displayed.

If true (default), all parameters are stored globally for the whole model. Otherwise the majoirty of parameters are stored locally for the respective kinetic equation they belong to. Note that some parameters represent global properties of the entire model and should therefore be always stored in the global list of prameters. In this way, these parameters are valid within the entire model.
If true, antisense RNA molecules are treated as enzymes when catalyzing a reaction. If false (default) antisense RNA molecule catalyzed reactions are not considered to be enzyme-catalyzed reactions.
If checked (default), complex molecules are treated as enzymes when catalyzing a reaction. Otherwise, complex catalyzed reactions are not considered to be enzyme reactions.
If true (default), generic proteins are treated as enzymes when catalyzing a reaction. Otherwise, generic protein-catalyzed reactions are not considered to be enzyme reactions.

If this options is selected, species that are annotated as macromolecules are treated as enzymes when catalyzing a reaction. Otherwise, macormolecule-catalyzed reactions are not considered enzyme reactions. If a modifier of a reaction that is annotated as an enzymatic catalyst refers to a macromolecule but this option is not active, SBMLsqueezer will reduce the modifier to a simple catalyst.
If true, receptors are treated as enzymes when catalyzing a reaction. If false (default), receptor catalyzed reactions are not considered to be enzyme reactions.
If true (default), RNA is treated as an enzyme when catalyzing a reaction. Otherwise RNA-catalyzed reactions are not considered to be enzyme-catalyzed reactions.
If true, simple molecules are treated as enzymes when catalyzing a reaction. If false (default), simple molecule catalyzed reactions are not considered to be enzyme reactions.
If true (default), truncated proteins are treated as enzymes when catalyzing a reaction. Otherwise, truncated protein catalyzed reactions are not considered to be enzyme reactions.
If true, unknown molecules are treated as enzymes when catalyzing a reaction. If false (default), unknown molecule catalyzed reactions are not considered to be enzyme reactions.
If true (default), parameters and units that are never referenced by any element of the model are automatically deleted after creating kinetic equations.
Set boundary condition for gene coding species
If true (default), the boundary condition of all species that represent gene-coding elements, such as genes or gene coding regions, will be set to true.
If true (default), SBML warnings are displayed.

This option ensures unit consistency and can attain two different values: Choose amount to bring each occurrence of a participating species to a substance unit. Depending on whether the species has only substance units or not it might be necessary to multiply the species with the size of its surrounding compartment. Choose concentration to bring each participating species to concentration units. In this case the species will be divided by the surrounding compartment size in a kinetic equations if it is defined to have only substance units. The units of parameters are set accordingly.

If this option is selected, species are interpreted in terms of concentration and are therefore divided by their surrounding compartment size when these occur in kinetic equations and their hasOnlySubstanceUnits attribute is false. The units of parameters are set accordingly.

If true (default), warnings will be displayed for reactions with an unrealistic number of reactants. The maximal number of reactants that are believed to be still realistic can be defined if this option is selected.
This option lets the user choose whether to search for kinetics in SABIO-RK.

Here you can specify how to deal with unknown values, how many reaction participants are still considered realistic, or which species should be ignored in kinetic equations for a smaller complexity of the equations.

Here you can choose how the unit consistency of your model should be ensured. Species can either be brought to units of concentration or amount. This selection influences how the compartment size is involved in the kinetic equation.
Species to be treated as enzymes

Since it is not always obvious, which species can be considered as an enzyme, i.e., a bio catalyst, you have the possibility to select types of species that you like to consider an enzyme in your model.
Model all reactions in a reversible manner
If true, all reactions are set to reversible before creating new kinetic equations. Otherwise the information given by the SBML file will be left unchanged.
If checked, the information about reversiblity will be left unchanged.
Choose version of modular rate laws

This option declares the version of the modular rate laws and can attain the three different values cat, hal and weg as described in the publications of Liebermeister et al. 2010. This option can only be accessed if all reactions are modeled reversibly.
Select the type of the default kinetic law for irreversible bi-bi reactions (two reactants, two products).
Choose the type of the default kinetic law for irreversible bi-uni reactions (two reactants, one product).

Determines the key for the standard kinetic law to be applied for reactions that are catalyzed by non-enzymes or that are not catalyzed at all. The value may be any rate law that implements InterfaceNonEnzymeKinetics
This key defines the default kinetic law to be applied to enzyme-catalyzed reactions with one reactant and one product.
Select the type of the default kinetic law for reversible bi-bi reactions (two reactants, two products).
Choose the type of the default kinetic law for reversible bi-uni reactions (two reactants, one product).

Determines the key for the standard kinetic law to be applied for reactions that are catalyzed by non-enzymes or that are not catalyzed at all. The value may be any rate law that implements InterfaceNonEnzymeKinetics
This key defines the default kinetic law to be applied to enzyme-catalyzed reactions with one reactant and one product.

Please specify the default kinetic law to be applied for reactions that are identified to belong to gene-regulatory processes (reactions involving genes, RNA, and proteins), such as transcription or translation.
Default rate law with zeroth order reactants
Default rate law with zeroth order products
Select the default rate law for each irreversible mechanism.
Select the default rate law for each reversible mechanism.
Select the default rate laws for gene-regulatory processes.

In some studies it has been found that treating all reactions as reversible processes comes closer to reality. Here you can select if you like to keep the given information about the reversibility of the reactions in the model as given, or if you prefer to set all reactions to reversible and create kinetic equations accordingly.
Here you can constrain your search for reaction kinetics in the online database SABIO-RK (System for the Analysis of Biochemical Pathways—Reaction Kinetics).
Search for kinetics of recombinant organisms
Search for entries containing kinetic data
Search for entries referring to journal publications
The lowest possible pH value for entries
The highest possible pH value for entries
The lowest possible temperature for entries (in °C).
The highest possible temperature for entries (in °C).
Consider only entries inserted after the specified date
Define the earliest acceptable date when the entries have been inserted into SABIO-RK.
Define key features to restrict the results of your search for reaction kinetics in SABIO-RK.
Define a plausible temperature range for your reaction system.
Constrict the selection of reaction kinetics to plausible conditions by selecting a meaningful range of pH values.
Here you can constrain your search for reaction kinetics in the online database SABIO-RK (System for the Analysis of Biochemical Pathways—Reaction Kinetics).
Define the pathway for which the kinetics are to be determined.
Define the tissue for which the kinetics are to be determined.
Define the cellular location for which the kinetics are to be determined.
Define the organism for which the kinetics are to be determined.
Define key options to restrict the results of your search for reaction kinetics in SABIO-RK.
